sanskrit:
आयुधानामहं वज्रं धेनूनामस्मि कामधुक् |
प्रजनश्चास्मि कन्दर्पः सर्पाणामस्मि वासुकिः ||२८||
transliteration:
āyudhānām ahaṁ vajraṁ dhenūnām asmi kāmadhuk |
prajanaś cāsmi kandarpaḥ sarpāṇām asmi vāsukiḥ ||28||
translation: Among weapons I am the thunderbolt; among cows I am the wish-fulfilling cow Kamadhuk. I am Kandarpa, the cause of procreation, and among serpents I am Vasuki.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna continues to enumerate His divine manifestations across various categories of existence. The vajra (thunderbolt) represents the most powerful and invincible weapon, wielded by Indra, symbolizing divine authority and irresistible force. Kamadhuk, the celestial wish-fulfilling cow that emerged from the churning of the cosmic ocean, represents abundance, nourishment, and the fulfillment of all desires. Krishna identifies Himself as Kandarpa (also known as Kamadeva), the deity of love and procreation, representing the creative force that perpetuates life and ensures the continuation of species. Among serpents, Vasuki is the king, who served as the rope during the churning of the cosmic ocean and adorns Lord Shiva's neck, symbolizing power, wisdom, and cosmic significance.

This verse illustrates Krishna's presence in the most excellent and powerful manifestations within each category. The progression from weapons to cows to procreation to serpents shows the diversity of divine manifestation—from instruments of destruction to sources of nourishment, from creative forces to beings associated with both danger and divine symbolism. Each example represents not just physical superiority but also carries deep symbolic and mythological significance in Hindu cosmology. Through these examples, Krishna teaches that the divine essence pervades all aspects of existence, from the most fearsome to the most benevolent, and that recognizing this divine presence in excellence leads to spiritual understanding and devotion.
speaker: Krishna
